event.headline: Ti West's twisted, bloddy slasher with a MAXXXINE sneak peek
event.description: Before Maxine Minx found stardom in the glitz and glam of Hollywood, she was in a little-seen “art” movie filmed at a remote farm in Texas. See how the budding starlet got her start at an exclusive fan event for Ti West’s bloody and titillating slasher, X. Not only will you get a chance to see Mia Goth’s star-making turn as the fame-hungry scream queen, you’ll get a 6-minute sneak peek at the upcoming finale of the terrifying trilogy, MAXXXINE. Plus, it’s on a Tuesday, so you’ll enjoy a discounted price on every ticket.

show.title: The Ultimate Willy Wonka Party
show.headline: Scrumdiddlyumptious

event.title: <show-title>The Ultimate Willy Wonka Party</show-title><event-type-title> with Live Q&A</event-type-title>
event.headline: See Willy Wonka with Mike Teevee and Veruca Salt in person!
event.description:
Come with me, and you'll be in a wooorld of pure imagination...and you'll also be in a theater with two of the original kids from WILLY WONKA & THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY! We'll have a full Q&A after the screening, so you can ask Paris Themmen (Mike TeeVee) what it was like to be so tiny and ask Julie Dawn Cole (Veruca Salt) what happened after she got dumped down the Bad Egg chute.

Plus, are you a Wonka fanatic? Dress as your favorite character, set piece, or prop from the film and compete in our scrumdiddlyumptious gummy bear eating contest!

Whether you're a kid or just a kid at heart, this candy-colored movie is a delightful confection that you'll enjoy again and again. And for this screening, we're pulling out all the stops with custom chocolate bars (of course!), golden goose feathers, and a whole lot more. We'd hate to ruin it all for you, so sign the contract on the bottom line and enter the magical world of Willy Wonka…

show.title: Hot Fuzz
show.headline: Edgar Wright's silly deconstruction of the buddy cop genre

event.title: <show-title>Hot Fuzz</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Big cops. Small town. Moderate violence.
event.description:
By the power of Greyskull, join us for an interactive celebration of director Edgar Wright’s balls-to-the-wall supercop comedy masterpiece, HOT FUZZ! Wright and his collaborators Simon Pegg and Nick Frost do to action cinema what they did to horror in SHAUN OF THE DEAD: They walk the cleverest of lines between homage, parody, and downright badass awesomeness. And when you model yourself after movies like POINT BREAK and BAD BOYS II, how could the results be anything but spectacular?

We’re even equipping you with everything you need to join the Sandford Police Service, including police badges, mustaches, and aviator glasses.

show.title: Purple Rain
show.headline: Purify yourself in the waters of Lake Minnetonka

event.title: <show-title>Purple Rain</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Pay tribute to the life, the music, and the legacy of Prince
event.description:
Dearly beloved, we are gathered here 2day 2 get through this thing called life – and to celebrate the legacy of the visionary and singular musical force that was Prince.

PURPLE RAIN is the semi-autobiographical tale of The Kid, a Minneapolis musician navigating the club scene while dealing with a romantic rival and a difficult family life. A massive hit upon release, it's a showcase for the Purple One’s otherworldly musical, visual, and sartorial stylings, and introduced the world to the glory of "When Doves Cry," "Let's Go Crazy," and of course, "Purple Rain." Join us in honoring His Royal Badness with a rockin’ Movie Party featuring purple shades, inflatable guitars, and funky fiber optic wands – in purple, of course.

As the man himself once sang, “U better live now.” Words 2 live by.

event.title: <show-title>UHF</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Don't touch that dial!
event.description:
To celebrate the cult comedy UHF, we're throwing a Movie Party! Not only do you get to watch this uproarious classic with a theater full of fellow "Weird Al" fans, but we'll also have all sorts of fun props to help you get in on the action, including TV signal glasses, gummy hot dogs, and fake mustaches.

So throw on a Hawaiian shirt, grab a spatula, and join us as we cheer on "Weird Al" in his fight to keep his local UHF station out of the hands of evil corporate overlords.

show.title: Grease
show.headline: Summer lovin' lives on in this quintessential movie musical celebrating the '50s

event.title: <show-title>Grease</show-title> <event-type-title>Sing-Along Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Warm up your pipes for a systematic, hydromatic sing-along
event.description:
We’re hopelessly devoted to GREASE, with its lovable characters, doo-wop style, and, of course, those endlessly catchy tunes. To celebrate this timeless classic, we’re putting together an interactive, prop-filled, hand-jiving Sing-Along Movie Party for all you T-Birds and Pink Ladies out there (beauty school dropouts also welcome).

We’ll kick things off with a pre-show hand jive contest before we start the interactive show, where you’ll have some candy cigarettes to help you look like a greaser, a comb so that you can comb along to the action, pom poms in Rydell High colors, and beauty caps to help you get the perfect ‘do. And because this is a Sing-Along, we’ll have the lyrics up onscreen to help every Danny, Sandy, Rizzo, and Kenickie in the audience get in on the fun.

So roll up the cuffs on those jeans, grab your respective black leather and pink satin jackets, theatrically comb your hair, and cruise on down to join us for the most rockin’ Sing-Along Movie Party ever.

DCP courtesy of Paramount Pictures

show.title: Jaws (1975)
show.headline: Steven Spielberg's terrifying creature feature

event.title: <show-title>Jaws (1975)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: A bigger boatload of bite-y fun
event.description:
“This shark, swallow you whole.”

Duh, nuh…duh, nuh…nothing quite says "ah, summer" like watching an elusive giant shark terrorize Amity Island on the big screen. It’s the movie that perfected the summer blockbuster and launched a million toothy (and goofy) knock-offs, but none of them can compete with the bite of Spielberg’s 1975 original. This bona fide American classic has everything you could want from a movie: kids in peril, drunken sea shanties, and Richard Dreyfuss in a cage.

As if that wasn’t enough, this is a Movie Party, so you can live the shark-hunting adventure along with your pals Brody, Hooper, and Quint – minus the salty sea air and actual mortal peril. Featuring Shark Hats, Yellow Floatie Drink Holders (CAUTION: very susceptible to shark attacks), and other surprises, it’s the most fourth-wall-busting fun you can have on dry land.

show.title: Steel Magnolias
show.headline: Big hair, big laughs, and a few tears

event.title: <show-title>Steel Magnolias</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: It takes effort to party like this
event.description:
Join us for a trip to the best place on Earth, home of big hair and even bigger gossip: Truvy's Beauty Spot.

In this charming little parlor, you don't just get your hair and nails did – you get vital life lessons, like the fact that there's no such thing as natural beauty. Thanks, Truvy Jones (Dolly Parton)! Then there's Clairee Belcher (Olympia Dukakis), reminding you that the only thing that separates us from the animals is our ability to accessorize. And without Ouiser Boudreaux (Shirley MacLaine), how would you discover that it's possible to be in a bad mood for 40 years?

So tease up your hair, grab your bestie, and join us for this special interactive screening of STEEL MAGNOLIAS, featuring fun surprises like armadillo squeeze toys, beauty caps, and more. You’ll laugh, cry, and quote along with the fiercest females in the South. It'll be even better than a slice of armadillo cake.

show.title: Firestarter (1984)
show.headline: Will she have the power...to survive?

event.title: <show-title>Firestarter (1984)</show-title>
event.headline: Will she have the power...to survive?
event.description:
No matter what script you start with, any film with the stars of PATTON, APOCALYPSE NOW, and E.T. – all directed by the guy who did CLASS OF 1984 – is gonna turn out pretty wonderful. What a bonus, then, to have it be a whackadoo Stephen King adaptation! Originally published during the snowstorm of King’s heavy-duty, well-publicized cocaine years, FIRESTARTER’s telekinesis conspiracy plot makes as much sense as a Weng Weng movie, but who cares? It’s worth the price of admission alone to see the audacious dialogue scenes between a karate-chopping George C. Scott and a pissed-off eight-year-old Drew Barrymore. Add a Martin Sheen that’s somehow even more oily than his DEAD ZONE counterpart, a John Carpenter-like score by Tangerine Dream, and enough pyro to outdo a Metallica stadium show, and you’ve got a late-night, three-beers genre bull's eye.

DCP courtesy of Universal Pictures

show.title: Crimes of Passion
show.headline: She is watched. She is worshipped. And she must remain a mystery.

event.title: <show-title>Crimes of Passion</show-title>
event.headline: Ken Russell's combustible erotic thriller
event.description:
“I am the messenger of God, you little cocksucker!”

Where do we even begin…y’all, we love some Ken Russell over here in the House of Theory. Ken was known for their flamboyant and controversial films that spanned decades and genres. From the Academy Award-winning drama WOMEN IN LOVE to the bizarre and hedonistic historical horror THE DEVILS to his many biopics of romantic-era composers, Russell tried it all. CRIMES OF PASSION, written by gay screenwriter Barry Sandler, is one of Russell’s few films firmly rooted in the era it was born into: the excessive and turbulent '80s. Joanna Crane (Kathleen Turner) is a frustrated fashion designer who moonlights as a sex worker under the alias China Blue. When she begins a complicated and intimate relationship with unsatisfied surveillance freelancer Bobby Grady (John Laughlin), Joanna’s delicately balanced life begins to topple. Meanwhile, psychotic street preacher Peter Shayne (Anthony Perkins) stalks Joanna, intent on “saving” her immortal soul no matter what it takes. THIS MOVIE IS NUTS, Y’ALL. CRIMES had a tumultuous path to the screen after the MPAA threatened to brand it with the dreaded X rating due to its salacious subject matter. After a death by a thousand cuts, the film was released to middling and confused reviews, AND YET we here a Queer Film Theory 101 think CRIMES OF PASSION is one of Russel’s most important and searing interrogations of repression, sexuality, religion, and otherness. And it is mad queer and deviant in all the right ways: there’s a metal murder dildo called Superman, y’all. Join us for a little taste of summertime smut – it’ll be good for you. We promise.

show.title: Footloose (1984)
show.headline: The music is on his side

event.title: <show-title>Footloose (1984)</show-title>
event.headline: The music is on his side
event.description: It’s time to lace up your Converse high tops and hit the abandoned industrial facility for some anxiety-fueled dance gymnastics because this month, Queer Film Theory 101 is cutting FOOTLOOSE. The small conservative rural community of Bomont is rocked when androgynous Chicago teen Ren McCormick (Kevin Bacon) moves to town and rejects the local ban on dancing. A town with no dancing? Jump back! That sounds an awful lot like a town with a drag ban, and that’s some bullshit. Also wouldn’t that be remarkably hard to enforce? Because I’m wiggling my hips while I’m writing this and who’s gonna stop me? Now, sometimes the queer read we posit on Queer Film Theory 101 is a stretch, but that is simply not the case when it comes to this '80s classic. From Bacon and Chris Penn’s “Let’s Hear It For The Boy” homoerotic dance lessons to the religious overtones of Reverend Shaw’s (John Lithgow) vendetta against undulating bodies, this movie is pretty damn camp. It’s not a huge leap in logic to see how “dancing” in FOOTLOOSE is a metaphor for queerness. Hell, there’s even a church “coming out” scene, and Dianne Wiest and Sarah Jessica Parker are in this movie – it’s for the gays and the dolls, y’all. While FOOTLOOSE wasn’t exactly well received critically (Roger Ebert called it “a seriously confused movie that tries to do three things, and does all of them badly” and that shit sounds pretty damn queer to me) the film and its soundtrack were commercial hits and skyrocketed Bacon to stardom. See you on the dance floor, baby!

show.title: Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!
show.headline: A love story...with strings attached

landscapeHeroImage.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

portraitHeroImage.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

posterImages.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

event.title: <show-title>Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!</show-title>
event.headline: Another unmissable Almodóvar/Banderas collaboration.
event.description:
“You'd better tie me up.”

We’re getting un poquito controversial here at Queer Film Theory 101! While most of the films we screen are box office hits that we extract queerness from, this month we’re examining one of the earliest films to receive an NC-17 rating: Pedro Almodovar’s divisive classic TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

When “cured” psychiatric patient Ricky (Antonio Banderas) finds himself adrift and alone after release, he fixates on B-movie and pornographic film star Marina (Victoria Abril), enacting a plan to kidnap her in the hope that she will fall in love with him.

Following on the heels of his star-making film WOMEN ON THE VERGE OF A NERVOUS BREAKDOWN, TIE ME UP! maintains a complicated relationship with viewers and critics alike (Roger Ebert said the film made him “feeling increasingly left out,” and to that, we say, "Sweetheart, if you wanna be tied up too, you just have to ask). While some viewers bristle at the film's more problematic elements, many find it an excellent critique of gender dynamics with a sly sense of humor. Interrogating themes of consent, coercion, sanism, and bondage, TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN! is a hilarious and uncomfortable investigation into the gilded cage of heteronormativity from one of our favorite queer directors, and we highly recommend you take this opportunity to catch it on the big screen. Note: we “recommend” it, meaning we won't make you watch it. Let’s go agency! Let’s go autonomy! Let’s go enthusiastic consent! (Micheal Foulk)

DCP courtesy of Janus Films.

Queer Film Theory 101 at Alamo Drafthouse takes an in-depth look at the queerest “straight” films ever produced. We’re outing all of your favorite films! Is TITANIC a genderqueer love story? Yeah! Does POINT BREAK explore latent homosexuality in sports culture? Absolutely. Is JAWS about the violent fear of queer desire? Yes yes, and we’ll tell you why. To this day there are so few representations of LGBTQ+ people in film, so we improvise, we read between the lines, we make adjustments to our head cannon, and zero in on all the queer subtext available. Join us every month for a new entry in our screening and lecture series. Hosted in-person in San Francisco; pre-recorded introductions elsewhere.

show.title: Battle Royale (2000)
show.headline: Could you kill your best friend?

event.title: <show-title>Battle Royale (2000)</show-title>
event.headline: A symphony of ultra-violence
event.description:
Welcome to your new favorite anxiety machine. Mixing high-octane action with nerve-shredding horror, BATTLE ROYALE finds a group of high school students stranded on an island with only one means of survival: KILL! The final film from legendary genre filmmaker Kinji Fukasaku and a major influence on everything from KILL BILL to THE HUNGER GAMES, this is a subversive symphony of ultra-violence that doubles as an artful examination of the abuse of power.

Screening a 4K restoration of the original theatrical cut

show.title: Cabin Fever
show.headline: Eli Roth's horror breakthrough.

event.title: <show-title>Cabin Fever</show-title>
event.headline: Eli Roth's horror breakthrough.
event.description:
"'Pancakes!' Eli Roth’s debut feature takes a different approach to the traditional “cabin in the woods” horror story. The tropes are all there: four friends heads to a cabin for sex, drugs, and a good time; a creepy gas station attendant provides foreboding warnings; strange visitors; a creaking old house. But what makes this movie unique—and really, really gross—is that the horror doesn’t arrive in the form of a mad human killer, but rather as a very contagious flesh-eating virus. Inspired by a trip during which Roth got a skin infection, Cabin Fever taps into our fears of the unknown—and the unknown’s tendency to suddenly emerge in our lives. It’s also even more terrifyingly relevant in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Make no mistake, this film is a fun ride made by folks who love a good horror film. It’s just that this one will get under your skin for quite a while." (NY Museum of Modern Art)

35mm print courtesy of Lionsgate.

show.title: Child's Play 2
show.headline: Chucky's gonna get you f*ckers

event.title: <show-title>Child's Play 2</show-title>
event.headline: Chucky's gonna get you f*ckers
event.description:
A high water mark in Chucky’s potty-mouthed legacy, CHILD’S PLAY 2 is a near-perfect sequel to a movie about a doll that has been possessed by a Satan-worshiping serial killer. This is an electric slasher that picks up where the first movie left off, bridging the darkness of the first film with John Waters-esque humor that would soon define the franchise. Written by series creator Don Mancini, the movie also features starring roles from Grace Zabriskie (Laura Palmer’s mom on TWIN PEAKS) and Christine Elise (the person who blew up a boat on BEVERLY HILLS 90210). What could be better? Only the moment when Chucky screams, "I'M GONNA GET YOU F*CKERS!"

Screening an archival 35mm print.

show.title: Exorcist III
show.headline: A criminally overlooked nerve-shredder from author William Peter Blatty.

event.title: <show-title>Exorcist III</show-title>
event.headline: A criminally overlooked nerve-shredder from author William Peter Blatty.
event.description:
Seventeen years after the events in THE EXORCIST, Lieutenant Kinderman (George C. Scott) investigates Satanic slayings that have all the hallmarks of a killer named The Zodiac Killer -- oops! -- we mean, The Gemini Killer. Trouble is, Gemini died in an electric chair many years ago. Or did he?! After years of development hell, John Carpenter was set to direct this sequel. But he convinced EXORCIST author William Peter Blatty to take the helm, resulting in the secret classic known as THE EXORCIST III. A cracking mix of doom-laden scares and capital “A” ACT-OFFS between George C. Scott and Brad Dourif (CHILD’S PLAY), this criminally overlooked nerve-shredder finds the perfect balance between big-budget sheen and pulpy thrills. Plus, where else can you see model Fabio and New York Knicks center Patrick Ewing as Angels of Death?

Screening from a collector's 35mm print.

show.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer
show.headline: The creator of SCREAM brings us another sexy teen thriller

landscapeHeroImage.altText: I KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER

portraitHeroImage.altText: I KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER

posterImages.altText: I know what you did last summer ver2 xlg 960x1400

event.title: <show-title>I Know What You Did Last Summer</show-title>
event.headline: The greatest July 4th slasher
event.description:
July 4th isn’t July 4th without friends, fireworks, and a maniacal fisherman with a bloody hook. The follow-up to SCREAM from writer Kevin Williamson and an adaptation of Lois Duncan’s iconic YA novel, I KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER is the world’s greatest July 4th slasher. With over-the-top dialogue (“I understand your pain!”), brutal violence, and a ringside seat to see Jennifer Love Hewitt, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Freddie Prinze, Jr., and Ryan Phillippe out-outrage each other, this is a dreamy middle ground between Dawson's Creek and PROM NIGHT that we’ll never stop loving.

Screening an archival 35mm print in San Francisco and Austin. Screening the digital presentation in Raleigh.

show.title: Maximum Overdrive
show.headline: Maximum Terror. Maximum King.

event.title: <show-title>Maximum Overdrive</show-title>
event.headline: Stephen King's manic big-rig thrillride.
event.description:
If there’s one thing that keeps Stephen King fans coming back again and again, it’s that the man knows how to have fun. Mixed into his catalog of highbrow horror and tender dramas are pulpy, over-the-top beach reads full of juicy characters and bloody mayhem. That’s where MAXIMUM OVERDRIVE fits in.

Written and directed by King himself, the film centers around the Dixie Boy, a mom 'n' pop truck stop under siege after a bizarro cosmic incident infects every Earthly machine from lawnmowers to giant 18-wheelers with a thirst for murder. High-octane havoc ensues.

With a great cast led by Emilio Estevez, a slammin’ soundtrack by none other than AC/DC, and loads of gore and goofball humor, MAXIMUM OVERDRIVE is the ultimate in Stephen King excess.

Screening from a collector's 35mm print.

event.description:

As she sinks deeper into her latest assignment Vos becomes trapped inside a mind that threatens to obliterate her.

This film is not rated but recommended for an adult audience due to intense violence

event.title: <show-title>The Lost Boys</show-title>
event.headline: Born to shop, born to kill
event.description: Co-created and written by Janice Fischer and directed by gay filmmaker Joel Schumacher (BATMAN FOREVER), THE LOST BOYS is the most soul-enriching vampire experience of the 1980s. This movie overflows with neon-lit blood-suckers, incredible fashion, and unreal saxophone solos played by ripped bodybuilders. It’s also the perfect conduit for the combined mega-powers of icons Corey Haim, Corey Feldman, Kiefer Sutherland, Jason Patric, and Jami Gertz. “Death by stereo,” indeed.

show.title: The Ring
show.headline: Before you die, you see...the ring

event.title: <show-title>The Ring</show-title>
event.headline: 4K restoration of the analog horror hit
event.description:
We'd follow Naomi Watts and her cursed VHS tape to the ends of the galaxy. THE RING – Gore Verbinski's expansive interpretation of the J-horror classic RINGU – is the rare horror remake that stands on its own as a singularly haunting experience. With a magnetic performance from David Lynch alumni Watts (MULHOLLAND DRIVE), a gorgeous design sensibility, and special effects by Rick Baker (VIDEODROME), it's no surprise that this movie scarred/inspired an entire generation of analog horror-heads. Or that it continues to resonate decades later.

Screening the 4K restoration

show.title: Deadbeat at Dawn
show.headline: Jim Van Bebber's brain-annihilating action splatterfest.

event.title: <show-title>Deadbeat at Dawn</show-title>
event.headline: Jim Van Bebber's brain-annihilating action splatterfest.
event.description:
“Jim Van Bebber’s shot-on-16mm masterpiece came careening out of Dayton, Ohio in 1988 like a runaway lawnmower blade, setting the standard for all nihilist street-gang movies to follow. Visceral, unspeakably violent, and fearless, Van Bebber could have easily lost his life making this film. You may lose yours watching it.” -- Austin Film Society

The absolute definition of DIY filmmaking, DEADBEAT AT DAWN is a cult classic that deserves the moniker -- an indie revenge movie with more thrills and bloody spills than all of Chuck Norris’ films combined.

‘80s visionary wunderkind Jim Van Bebber wrote, directed, did stunts and makeup FX for and starred in this raucous tale of Goose: a former gang leader whose girlfriend is slaughtered when he leaves the thug life behind. As he’s pulled back into the gang during an uneasy alliance with the murdering thugs, Goose exacts his head-crushing revenge…

You will not believe your eyes when you see Van Bebber giving 1,000% during every frame of this film.

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive.

show.title: Double Agent 73
show.headline: "Watch out for the booby traps...they're explosive!"

event.title: <show-title>Double Agent 73</show-title>
event.headline: "Watch out for the booby traps...they're explosive!"
event.description:
Panic strikes the badly wallpapered and shag-carpeted dens of the criminal underground: feds are hot on the tail of a mysterious kingpin known as Toplar. His pursuer? Secret agent Jane Tennay. Her weapons? Platform high-heels and cameras implanted in her mind-bogglingly large breasts, of course. Keep all arms and legs inside the vehicle, please – you're entering the wacked-out world of DOUBLE AGENT 73, sexploitation director Doris Wishman's magnum opus.

Released back-to-back with the equally absurd DEADLY WEAPONS, DOUBLE AGENT 73 is the campier and more entertaining of Wishman's collaborations with the titanically-endowed burlesque performer Chesty Morgan. Bringing a distinctly feminine and sincere touch to her low-budget sexploitation, Wishman collides a softcore spy novel with hilarious violence, alien filmmaking techniques, and all the wildest '70s fashions you can imagine; a brain-boiling car crash of detective pulp and high-femme kitsch. A favorite of John Waters, Frank Henenlotter, and many other directors with good taste in bad taste, DOUBLE AGENT 73 is essential viewing for those who find normal cinema will no longer cut it. (Morgan Hyde)

2K restoration courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: Gwendoline
show.headline: Recently rediscovered uncut version!

event.title: <show-title>Gwendoline</show-title>
event.headline: An adults-only adventure
event.description:
“It’s like if scenes were cut from Indiana Jones and fleshed out with half-naked babes in sci-fi bondage with the comic book flare of BARBARELLA and led into the desert by a young Tawni Kitaen, pre-Whitesnake.” – ronniespectre, Letterboxd

In the ‘70s, he created a daring new world of X-rated cinema with EMMANUELLE and THE STORY OF O. And in 1984, Just Jaeckin wrote and directed GWENDOLINE – the most ambitious and audacious classic of his legendary career. Video vixen Tawny Kitaen (WITCHBOARD) and action hero Brent Huff (NINE DEATHS OF THE NINJA) star in this kinky Indiana Jones riff. Based on an infamous S&M comic strip and bursting with perilous adventure, spectacular production design, and eye-popping lesbian bondage, GWENDOLINE has been newly scanned in 4K from the original negative. (AGFA)

DCP Courtesy of Severin Films and AGFA

show.title: Howard The Duck
show.headline: Not bad for a duck from outer space...

event.title: <show-title>Howard The Duck</show-title>
event.headline: Not bad for a duck from outer space...
event.description:
Back in 1986, Lucasfilm and Universal thought it would be a good idea to bring an anthropomorphic duck named Howard to screen in live-action glory. He’s a private eye! He talks! He carries condoms made for ducks! Somehow, the powers that be thought there was a recipe for success here...and boy were they right.

HOWARD THE DUCK is typically regarded as a flop and a completely misguided attempt at giving us a talking duck movie. But it’s bigger than that. HOWARD THE DUCK straddles the line between careful adaptation and a reimagining of a property as something decidedly different (and perhaps much more adult) than its source material would suggest.

It’s not every day that you get a studio-produced comic book movie from the director of MESSIAH OF EVIL, the creator of STAR WARS, and features a cigar-chomping duck who thinks he’s Sam Spade and has a lust for human women. Cherish it. It’ll never happen again.

show.title: Surf II: The End of the Trilogy
show.headline: Atomic-powered absurdist comedy.

event.title: <show-title>Surf II: The End of the Trilogy</show-title><event-type-title> with Special Menu</event-type-title>
event.headline: Atomic-powered absurdist comedy to the maxxx.
event.description:
Don’t look for SURF I, because no such movie exists. In fact, there has never been another movie even remotely like SURF II. From the outside it looks a lot like a typical “teens just wanna have fun” comedy, but in reality, it’s the single most anarchic comedy of the decade, spring-loaded with non sequiturs, cultural satire, truly great comedic performances, and fun, fun, fun.

When a pair of bad dads decide their beach neighborhood is overdue for gentrification, they enlist evil nerd scientist Eddie Deezen to create a cola formula that will turn all surfers into brain dead automatons. Some of the surfers have other ideas, and so does director Randall Badat, who turns every scene into an off-kilter masterpiece of energy, invention, and (yep) pure cinema. (Lars Nilsen)

DCP courtesy of Vinegar Syndrome and AGFA.

show.title: The Lighthouse
show.headline: Hark, and take heed of Robert Eggers' mind-bending tale of madness at sea

event.title: <show-title>The Lighthouse</show-title>
event.headline: "Yer fond of me lobster, ain't ye?"
event.description:
With THE WITCH (or VVITCH, if you're so inclined), Robert Eggers blasted onto the genre scene with a folk horror fury. His follow-up, THE LIGHTHOUSE, turns his obsession with the past to the edge of the 1900s. Robert Pattinson is Thomas, the new keeper for a mysterious New England island; Willem Dafoe is also Thomas, a grizzled veteran of the seafaring life.

A deeply unromantic view of romanticized maritime fiction, THE LIGHTHOUSE takes the SpongeBob ethos of nautical nonsense to the fullest extent, with two tour-de-force performances that range from cosmic terror to psychedelic humor, almost simultaneously. (Jake Isgar)

show.title: Torque
show.headline: Extreme motorcycle mayhem in 35mm

event.title: <show-title>Torque</show-title>
event.headline: Extreme motorcycle mayhem in 35mm
event.description:
For those who feel THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS movies have only gotten better as they've gotten more and more ridiculous, take a look back to 2004 and see that Joseph Kahn and his team beat that franchise to the NOS-injected punch. Shot like a commercial for music videos and edited within an inch of coherency, TORQUE is peak '00s extreme pop art. Indistinguishable from parody even when it's ambiguous if that's what it's up to, and still thrillingly over-the-top even when it's clear that it's making fun of itself. Don't worry, you can't get irony poisoning in just 84 brief minutes, and you'll be left wanting more of this looney tune.

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus

show.title: Wake in Fright
show.headline: An Ozploitation classic.

event.title: <show-title>Wake in Fright</show-title>
event.headline: An Ozploitation classic.
event.description:
Alongside MAD MAX and WALKABOUT, WAKE IN FRIGHT is widely acknowledged as one of the seminal films in the development of modern Australian cinema. Directed by Ted Kotcheff (FIRST BLOOD) and starring Donald Pleasence (HALLOWEEN), WAKE IN FRIGHT tells the nightmarish story of a schoolteacher’s descent into personal demoralization at the hands of drunken, deranged derelicts while stranded in a small town in the Australian Outback. Believed to be lost for decades and virtually unseen in America until now, WAKE IN FRIGHT returns fully-restored in what the New York Observer says “may be the greatest Australian film ever made.”

DCP courtesy of Umbrella Entertainment and AGFA.

show.headline: Some superheroes are cuter than others

event.title: <show-title>Wicked City</show-title>
event.headline: Mutant noir from producer Tsui Hark.
event.description:
Okay, we’re cheating with this one: it isn’t really based on a manga. It’s based on a novel, but you’d never know because it’s full of the types of images of be-tentacled monsters and kinetic action one would expect from a manga adaptation. This live-action Hong Kong movie followed a Japanese animated adaptation of the source novel from five years earlier, but with producer Tsui Hark behind the scenes, expect this version to push the very limits of visual comprehensibility and budget

DCP courtesy of Filmworkshop.

show.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans
show.headline: The only criminal he can't catch is himself.

posterImages.altText: Bad lieutenant port of call new orleans lobby poster

event.title: <show-title>Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans</show-title>
event.headline: Cage & Herzog go wild in The Big Easy.
event.description:
"Shoot him again!"
"What for?"
"His soul is still dancing."

Nominally a remake of the Abel Ferrara/Harvey Keitel film, or perhaps an entry in the BAD LIEUTENANT Cinematic Universe, PORT OF CALL NEW ORLEANS relocates from a wrecked New York City to the post-Katrina Big Easy. Terence McDonagh (A rarified Nicolas Cage) wades through the underbelly of New Orleans on a perpetual bender of pain-killers, cocaine, and an assortment of transgressions -- he is the Bad Lieutenant, after all -- to get to the bottom of a drug deal gone wrong. Marrying his trademark mega-acting with Herzog's fascination for outsized weirdos, Cage goes full Kinski in one of the most brazenly entertaining roles of his now heavily-meme'd career. Join us for a special 10th Anniversary celebration to a real one, and help answer the question "what are these fuckin' iguanas doing on my coffee table?" (Jake Isgar)

DCP courtesy of FilmRise.

show.title: Ginger Snaps
show.headline: They don't call it the curse for nothing

event.title: <show-title>Ginger Snaps</show-title>
event.headline: The feminist werewolf parable for the 21st Century.
event.description:
"A perfect women's horror picture." - Willow Maclay, Letterboxd

One of the dumbest prejudices perpetuated by the world is that menstrual cycles turn women into monsters. That conceit is what makes GINGER SNAPS so incredible. The Fitzgerald sisters are death-obsessed high school goths who create ultra-violent art projects while battling the popular kids. But everything changes when someone’s period -- and a werewolf -- enters the picture. Combining the revisionist energy of AN AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON, the body-horror of SHIVERS, and the black humor of HAROLD AND MAUDE, GINGER SNAPS is unpredictable and unbelievably fun -- taking gender norms down a peg with lycanthropic glory.

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.
